newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain's Retevision sets terms for privatisation.
newsitem.headline: Spain's Retevision sets terms for privatisation.

text.p: Spanish state telecommunications group Retevision announced on Tuesday the terms for privatisation of a 60 percent stake in a restricted auction.
Retevision is expected to operate as Spain's second domestic telephone operator after Telefonica.
The initial 60 percent of Retevision to be sold comprises 2.4 million shares out of a total of 4.0 million shares and will be offered at a minimun price of 45.6 billion pesetas.
The prospective buyer must make a commitment to underwrite another 10 percent capital increase in Retevision, a company statement said.
Given a minimum price of 19,000 pesetas per share, the commitment would mean a further expenditure of 25.33 billion pesetas.
After the capital increase, the state will retain a diluted 30 percent stake, a spokesman said.
The prospectus for the privatisation is expected to be published on April 3. Interested buyers will have a first deadline on April 21 to present their formal bids.
Prospective buyers will have to provide warranties to back their bids.

In a second phase, ending on April 29, Retevision will designate a selected group of firms. From this day, bidders will have access to important information about Retevision such as results, balance sheets and clients information.
Final bids may be presented until June 9.
The final bids will be examined for no more than 60 days by a technical group.
Retevision, Spain's second telecommunications operator after Telefonica de Espana, is due to be fully privatised by 2000.
